metadata.sermon_start_end: The Hebrew word Shabbath, from which comes our word Sabbath, means "rest." Now I care not whether someone observes Saturday as the Sabbath or Sunday. I am sure that the people we need to worry about are those who observe no day as the day of rest and worship. [...] Then cometh the end, when God will be all in all. God above, God below, God all around, God within, God ahead. Forever! "There remaineth therefore a rest to the people of God" (Hebrews 4:9).

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first requirement. It is not an exposition of one specific passage but a thematic speech based on a 'biblical keyword' (Sabbath) and a 'biblical idea' (three stages of history). It jumps between Genesis, Corinthians, and Hebrews to support a pre-conceived systematic framework.
quotes: A man who should be better known than he is has suggested that the Bible speaks of three great Sabbaths
The first Sabbath... occurs in the account we have in Genesis
The second completion... occurred in our redemption
There is the promise of a third Sabbath... the consummation of the age
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Genesis 2:1-3 or Hebrews 4:1-11) and find what is unique to THAT text rather than using the Bible as a sourcebook for a thematic survey.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial. While the Hebrew 'Shabbath' is mentioned, there is no engagement with the specific historical or theological context of the quoted books. The preacher uses the texts as proof-texts for a general narrative rather than investigating what the text meant for the original readers.
quotes: The Hebrew word Shabbath... means 'rest.'
John says simply, 'He bowed his head.'
Hear how Paul states the matter in that soaring and surging fifteenth chapter
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond word definitions to historical-critical or theological exegesis. Explain the specific crisis or context Paul or the author of Hebrews was addressing.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (the blizzard in Boston/New York), but it often drifts into generalities about 'Western society' or 'sinning hearts.' It lacks the 'true truth' of specific ethical or spiritual demands.
quotes: Proud Boston stops, cultured Connecticut shuts down... sophisticated New York stalls.
The passing from our society of a generally accepted day of rest... is another sign in the weakening and decline of our Western society.
Let every sinning heart hear those tidings like the sweet sound of silver bells.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid sentimental language ('silver bells') and focus on the concrete 'lostness' or 'gratitude' of the specific congregation in their current social and spiritual reality.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'lecture' format: a point of 'exposition' (what the Bible says) followed by an illustration or application. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' so much as told about the text and then told an anecdote (e.g., the Battle of New Orleans).
quotes: This teaching instructs us that because God created the world...
One of the celebrated victories of American military history is the battle of New Orleans... Jackson and his army had not heard the news. And so, though Christ has died...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Stop using external anecdotes to explain the text; let the text's own internal logic and movement expose the hearer's life.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon clearly identifies misery (sin, sickness, death) and redemption (Christ's finished work). However, it leans heavily toward an objective 'history of salvation' rather than the subjective experience of the hearer. Gratitude is present but remains somewhat abstract.
quotes: Sin and sickness and sorrow and pain and motives misread and, yes, death.
The work of the Son, the life of Jesus Christ, represents the second great work of God.
How sweet to live life in its confidence.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' from physical suffering (sickness) to the theological misery of man before God, and make 'gratitude' a more concrete response of the Spirit.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely missing. While 'sinners' are mentioned, there is no real sense of the 'ultimate possibilities' or the danger of being lost. The tone is predominantly one of comfort and inevitable victory, which risks taking neither God nor man seriously in their responsibility.
quotes: I think they are just fools who just say such things.
The powers of hell have not received the communiqu√©, but the battle has been fought and won.
Never more can they fall or fail.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the 'narrow way.' Address the hearer as a 'willing and responsible being' whose choices in time have eternal weight.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos and the source of grace. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the description of the 'Bread of Life' becoming hungry. The focus on 'It is finished' aligns with Dekker's requirement of salvation outside oneself.
quotes: The centerpiece of our gospel is that God came among us in Jesus Christ...
For us the strength of God became weak and the Eternal bowed down to death.
At Calvary the word was 'It is finished.' Thus came the Sabbath of the Son.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'second stage' in a three-part plan, but the living Lord who confronts the hearer here and now.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon would take roughly 14-15 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' The thematic jumping prevents a deep drilling into a single text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition of a single passage to reach at least 20 minutes, allowing for more rigorous theological and psychological exploration.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's definition primarily because it is a thematic address ('a speech about a biblical keyword') rather than an exposition of a specific pericope. It lacks the 'two ways' and the necessary length for depth. It functions well as a Christocentric encouragement but fails the formal requirements of homiletic specificity and exegetical rigor.
strengths: Strong Christocentric focus on the 'finished work' of redemption.
Effective use of contemporary imagery (the blizzard) to illustrate human helplessness.
Clear articulation of the 'misery' of death and suffering.
weaknesses: Lack of a specific Bible passage as the 'starting point' (Thesis 1.3).
Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) to achieve theological breadth (Thesis 8).
Absence of the 'two ways' and the seriousness of human responsibility/lostness (Thesis 6).
Over-reliance on external anecdotes (Battle of New Orleans) rather than textual exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: By Dekker's criteria, this is not a sermon but a thematic speech. It lacks the 'recreating of a specific Bible passage into a new, current, proclamatory word.' It is too general and too short to be considered a 'right proclamation of the Gospel' in the strict sense.
